greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the least M such that A329914(n) * M = 1M1, where 1M1 denotes the concatenation of 1, M and 1.
comment: When M is a q-digit term, then M is a divisor of 10^(q+1) + 1.

For each term k in A329914, there exist a set of numbers M_k which, when 1 is placed at both ends of M_k, the number M_k is multiplied by k. This sequence gives the smallest integer M(k) = M of each set {M_k}.
See A329914 for further information about these numbers.
reference: D. Wells, 112359550561797732809 entry, The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers. Penguin Books, NY, 1986, Revised edition 1997, p. 196.
example: 33 * 4347826087 = 1[4347826087]1, and there is no integer < 4347826087 that satisfies this relation, so 4347826087 is a term with 10 digits and 23 * 4347826087 = 10^11 + 1 with 10 zeros in its decimal expansion.
results.author: _Bernard Schott_, Nov 24 2019
